statement.p:
Write each set with interval notation, and graph the set on a number line.
3 \le x \lt 6
x \ge -9
x \le 1~\text{or}~x\gt 4
-8 \lt x \le 5~\text{or}~-1\le x \lt 3

li.p: [3,6). This is called a half-open or half-closed interval. A square bracket indicates that the end-point is included; a round bracket that it is not included.
[-9, \infty). We use round brackets next to the symbol \infty because \infty is not a specific number and is not included in the set.
(-\infty,1] \cup (4, \infty). The word “or” describes the union of two sets. The symbol ~\cup~ is used for union.

statement.p:
Write each set with interval notation, and graph the set on a number line.
-5 \lt x \le 3
-6 \lt x \lt \infty
x \lt -3 ~\text{or}~ x\ge -1
-6 \le x \lt-4 ~\text{or}~ -2 \lt x \le 0
Solve the inequality ~-3 \lt 2x-5 \le 6~ and write your solution with interval notation.

solution.p: To isolate x, we first add 5 on each side of the inequality symbols. \begin{aligned}[t] -3 \amp \lt 2x-5 \le 6 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Add 5 on all three sides.}}\\ 2 \amp \lt 2x~~ \le 11 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide each side by 2.}}\\ 1 \amp \lt x \le \dfrac{11}{2} \end{aligned} The solutions are all real numbers greater than 1 but less than or equal to \dfrac{11}{2}. In interval notation, we write ~(1, \dfrac{11}{2}].
